Key Arguments: The Bill grants ACMA substantial, unilateral, and discretionary authority over media, threatening freedom of speech and expression.
The Bill is poorly drafted, lacking clear definitions and scope, which could lead to misapplication.
Freedom of speech and expression are fundamental rights that the Bill does not adequately protect.
The Bill could impede individuals' and businesses' rights to self-determination by restricting online expression.
There is concern over who decides what constitutes misinformation and disinformation, leading to potential arbitrary enforcement.
The Bill could result in censorship due to uncertainty and fear of liability.
The Bill lacks justification for its proposed intrusions into private and civil autonomy.
Notable Quotes: The Bill, if passed in its current form, would allow the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) substantial, unilateral and discretionary authority to govern all forms of media.
Our freedom of speech and expression deserves much more protection i.e what this Bill is NOT offering.
It is unlikely that minor amendments will be enough to save this Bill.
The truth will always rise to the top and be self-supporting so it is questionable why this Bill is required in the first place.
